instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message:
I have a macbook pro 2019 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with touch ID and Touch Bar that the power button is not responding. The touch ID itself works, but can get it to power on with the power button. It powers on if i connect the charger to it with the battery unplugged. Original issue was liquid spill but can't find any corrosion damage.
I swapped out the headphone jack/power connection board, which didn't fix the issue.
The laptop powers up and runs without any issue.
I've not been able to find a board view for this model, i'm assuming there's none.

Compared to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> J4810 pin 15, i'm get 2.2v instead of 3.3v.

Any suggestions. Will <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> touch ID/Power button work on this model (i know this will mean the touch ID portion won't work), as i'm about to order that to test the power button? The only other option is to order one from china.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message:
Some time ago, one member post few videos about recovering power button from Touch ID; in case of liquid spill.
You should find something searching on the forum...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message:
None of the videos i found worked. 

So I found the schematic, still searching for board view. Anyway, J6600 which is the same connector on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> J6600, 
pin 21 - <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_R_L_CONN</SIGNAL>

this pin is reading 1.7ohms with or without the power/audio jack cable connected. I'm assuming this won't be a normal measurement for this pin.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message:
I don't have 01598 schematic.
In 00840, I don't see that signal on J6600...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message: Yeah that signal isn't on 00840 board. J6600 is where the power/touchID and audio jack goes into. I checked in comparison to 00850 that has the same signal and touchID, the measurement was a large resistance and not the small ground resistance i have on the bad board. Unfortunately i'm now trying to find what looks like a flipflop <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> (same on the 00850 board).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_R_L_CONN</SIGNAL> cannot be shorted to ground.
In 00850 board, there is <RESISTOR>R4911</RESISTOR>; remove it to discard <CHIP>U6940</CHIP> issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Power button not responding
threads.message: Yep that’s the resistor I’m searching for. A little tricky with not board view.
